daptation, with the exception of compact cities, with trade
between mitigation and adaptation. This is because decreasing urban sprawl can increase the risks of
flooding and heat stress. Detailed mapping between mitigation and adaptation in urban area
there are many, very close interactions between the two policy domains and that coordinated governance
across sectors is therefore called for.
Rebuilding and refurbishment after climate hazards can increase energy consumption and GHG
emissions in the construction and building materials sectors, as
support implementation of the Sendai framework on disaster risk reduction
high temperatures, intense rainfall leading to flooding, more
d/or storms and sea level rises (SLRs) can seriously impact transport infrastructure,
the operations and mobility of road, rail, shipping and aviation; Chapter 10 assesses the
impacts on subsectors within transportation. At the same time, these s
ectors are major targets for GHG
mitigation options, and many countries are currently examining what to do in terms of combined
adaptation efforts, using the need to mitigate climate change through transport
pollutants as the basis for adaptation action
For example, urban sprawl indirectly affects climate processes, increasing emissions and
vulnerability, which worsens the ability to adapt
by passengers and freight will reduce the pressures on the roads, while having less urban sprawl will
reduce the impacts on new infrastructure, often in more vulnerable areas
Despite many links between mitigation and adaptation options, including synergies and trade
Chapter 13 concludes that there are few frameworks for integrated policy implementation. One
gislation in Europe found a lack of coordination between mitigation and adaptation,
implementation varying according to different national circumstances
In developing and least developed countries, there are many examples of climate policies in the NDCs
that have been drawn up in the context of sustainable development and
. However, there are many barriers to joint
policy implementation. Despite the emphasis on both mitigation and adaptation policies,
limited literature on how to design and implement integrated policies
. For example, the links within the water, energy and food nexus require coordination among
building in innovative frameworks linking science, pr
(Cook and Chu 2018; Nakano 2017; Shaw et al. 2014)
financial, technical and human resources for implementing joint
Agyei et al. 2018b; Chu 2018; David and Venkatachalam
Several studies have stressed that the lack of finance for
integrating policy implementation between sustainable development and climate
adaptation may constitute barriers to the implementation of adaptation projects t
come to similar conclusions regarding finance based on interviews with
multilateral development banks, green funds and government organizations in respect of the agricultural
and forestry sectors. International climate finance ha
s been totally dominated by mitigation projects.
